claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens antigen presentation, including expansion of the MHC-I peptidome in tumors.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Vaccination-associated tumor priming aligns with improved outcomes during checkpoint blockade, including better survival in the retrospective human cohort.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, and tumor-type plus treatment-history heterogeneity limits causal interpretation.

claims.claim: Type I interferon signaling appears mechanistically necessary for the sensitization effect.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors, so mechanistic dependence should be prospectively validated clinically.

claims.claim: The sensitization effect is conditional, because single-agent arms and non-mRNA particle controls did not replicate durable benefit.

evidence.quote: Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.
ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline settings.
Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.

claims.caveat: Some model systems showed stronger effects than others, indicating context dependence and limiting broad generalization across all tumor settings.
